data.event: On 8 July 2011 the central government approved Zhoushan as Zhoushan Archipelago New Area, a state-level new area.

event.title: 2010 census, its population was 1,121,261 whom 842,989 lived

data.event: At the 2010 census, its population was 1,121,261 whom 842,989 lived in the built-up area made of Dinghai and Putuo counties.
The archipelago was inhabited 6,000 years ago during the Neolithic by people of the Hemudu culture.
During the Spring and Autumn period, Zhoushan was called Yongdong (甬东), referring to its location east of the Yong River, and belonged to the State of Yue.

event.title: launched his rebellion around the year 400

data.event: Sun En, an adherent of the Taoist sect Way of the Five Pecks of Rice, launched his rebellion around the year 400 and was defeated by Jin forces in 402.

During the Ming dynasty, especially between the years 1530 and 1560, Japanese and Chinese pirates used Zhoushan as one of their principal bases from which they launched attacks as far as Nanjing; "the whole Chinese coast from northern Shandong to western Guangdong was ravaged to a distance of sixty miles inland."
